questions.text: A 30-year-old man who sustained a tibial fracture with a peroneal nerve palsy 2 years ago now has foot drop and weak eversion of the foot. He reports success with stretching exercises, but he catches his toes when his foot tires. Examination reveals that the foot is plantigrade and supple. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Posterior tibial tendon transfer to the cuboid

options.label: B
options.text: Anterior tibial tendon transfer to the cuboid

questions.correct_answer: D. Ankle-foot orthosis with dorsiflexion assist
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ankle-foot orthosis with dorsiflexion assist The patient has a supple plantigrade foot that would benefit from a foot drop brace to prevent the catching of the toes. Tendon transfer should not be considered until the patient has undergone bracing.

Highyeild:

Orthoses can be divided into static and dynamic types. Static orthoses are used: (i) to support an arthritic joint or a fractured bone; (ii) to prevent joint contractures in a paralytic limb; and (iii) for serial splinting of a joint to correct contracture. Dynamic orthoses are used to apply forces to a joint which is damaged by arthritis or when the muscles that normally control the joint are weak. USES OF ORTHOSES Orthoses are used for the following functions: To immobilise a joint or body part e.g., a painful joint To prevent a deformity e.g., in a polio limb To correct a deformity e.g., in Volkmann's contracture To assist movement e.g., in a polio limb To relieve weight bearing e.g., in an un-united fracture To provide support e.g., to a fractured spine Some common clinical conditions requiring orthoses are cervical spondylosis or whiplash injury (common cervical collar or cervical orthosis),

questions.text: What is the most common foot deformity associated with myelomeningocele?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Talipes equinovarus All of the above conditions can be associated with myelomeningocele, but talipes equinovarus occurs in 50% to 90% of patients with myelomeningocele.

Highyeild:

AETIOLOGY In the vast majority of cases, aetiology is not known, hence it is termed idiopathic. In others, the so called secondary clubfoot, some underlying cause such as arthrogryposis multiplex congenita (AMC) can be found. Idiopathic clubfoot : Following are some of the theories proposed for the aetiology of idiopathic clubfoot: Mechanical theory : The raised intrauterine pressure forces the foot against the wall of the uterus in the position of the deformity. Ischaemic theory : Ischaemia of the calf muscles during intrauterine life, due to some unknown factor, results in contractures, leading to foot deformities. Genetic theory: Some genetically related disturbances in the development of the foot have been held responsible for the deformity. Secondary clubfoot : Following are some of the causes of secondary clubfoot: Paralytic disorders: In a case where there is a muscle imbalance i.e., the invertors and plantar flexors are stronger than the evertors and dorsiflexors, an equino-varus deformity will develop. This occurs in paralytic disorders such as polio, spina bifida, myelodysplasia and Freidreich's ataxia. Arthrogryposis multiplex congenita (AMC) : This is a disorder of defective development of the muscles. The muscles are fibrotic and result in foot deformities, and deformities at other joints.

questions.correct_answer: B. Open reduction and internal fixation with screws
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Open reduction and internal fixation with screws Option: B. The displaced talar neck fracture should be treated with open reduction and internal fixation using screws.

Highyeild:

FRACTURES OF THE TALUS Minor fractures in the form of a small chip from the margins of one of the articular surfaces of the talus are more common than the more serious fracture i.e. fracture of the neck of the talus. RELEVANT ANATOMY Blood supply to the talus: This is the only bone of the foot without any muscle attachment. The main blood supply to the talus is from the anastomotic ring of blood vessels, the osseous vessels entering its neck and running postero-laterally within the bone to supply its body. Therefore, blood supply to the body of the talus is often cut off following fractures occurring through the neck.

Fracture of the lateral process of the talus Option: B. This mechanism of injury is typical for a lateral process of the talus fracture. These injuries are common in snowboarders. The mechanism involves dorsiflexion, axial loading, inversion, and external rotation . They are often missed and may require MRI, CT, or bone scanning to make the diagnosis. Undisplaced fractures can be treated in a cast. Displaced fractures ( > 2 mm) should be reduced and fixed, or excised if they are too small for fixation.

questions.text: Which of the following ligaments attaches to the sustentaculum tali?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Spring The spring ligament is the plantar calcaneonavicular and arises from the sustentaculum tali. The intertarsal ligaments in the foot are important for stability. The cervical is also termed the interosseous talocalcaneal. The bifurcate is composed of two ligaments, which are also termed calcaneocuboid and calcaneonavicular. The long plantar is also termed calcaneocuboid-metatarsal: it arises from the calcaneum and inserts into the cuboid and all five metatarsals. The short plantar is the plantar calcaneocuboid. The spring ligament is the plantar calcaneonavicular and arises from the sustentaculum tali.

Highyeild:

The plantar calcaneonavicular ligament also referred to as the spring ligament is a thick wide band of cartilaginous connective tissue that supports the medial longitudinal arch of the foot, failure in the spring ligament leads to flat foot deformity.

questions.text: A 15 years old girl complains of anterior knee pain which increases on going upstairs and getting up after prolonged sitting. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chondromalacia Patellae Adolescents with anterior knee pain are usually found to have Chondromalacia patellae, An adolescent or young adult complains of an ache in the front of the knee (occasionally both knees), With intermittent episodes of clicking or ‘giving way’. There may be a history of trauma or markedly Increased activity. Symptoms are aggravated by exercise or climbing stairs, especially if this follows a long period of sitting. It is often (but not invariably) associated with softening and fibrillation of the articular surface of the patella – chondromalacia patellae

Highyeild:

Condromalacia patella Chondromalacia of the patella occurs in adolescents and young adults. The condition is more common in females. It can be related to the abnormal position of the knee. Symptoms: A grating or grinding sensation when the knee is flexed Knee pain in the front of the knee that occurs when you get up after sitting for a long period of time Knee pain that worsens when you use stairs or get out of a chair Knee tenderness Treatment Temporarily resting the knee and taking nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) Stretch the muscles on the back (hamstrings) and front (quadriceps) of upper leg.

questions.text: The medial meniscus of the knee joint is injured more often than the lateral meniscus because the medial meniscus is relatively?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Less mobile The medial meniscus is much less mobile than the lateral, and it cannot as easily accommodate abnormal stresses. This may be why meniscal lesions are more common on the medial side than on the lateral.

Highyeild:

Medial and Lateral meniscus McMurray's test: With the patient in supine position the knee is acutely and forcibly flexed. The foot is rotated externally. Now the examiner palpates the posteromedial margin of the joint with one hand and by other the foot if firmly grasped. Now the knee is slowly extended. As the femur passes over the torn part of the meniscus a click may be heard. The angle of flexion at which the symptoms occurs indicates the position of the tear. The more posterior is the tear, the more flexed position of the knee is when the sign becomes positive. For lateral meniscus similar test with the foot internally rotated and examiner's hand palpating the posterolateral aspect of knee is carried out. Apley's grinding test : The patient lies prone on the couch. The knee is flexed to 90 degree and the thigh is fixed to the examination table by placing one hand on the back of the thigh. The surgeon now applies compression along the long axis of the tibia while rotating it medially and laterally on the femur (grinding movement). Pain on lateral rotation indicates a medial meniscal tear while that on medial rotation indicates a lateral meniscal tear. Medial meniscus is more frequently torn than the lateral because the medial meniscus is securely attached around the entire periphery of the joint capsule, which makes it less mobile. The lateral meniscus is more mobile and has no weak point between a movable and relatively fixed point. Popliteus muscle sends few fibers into the posterior margin of lateral meniscus. Thus muscle contraction withdraws & protects the lateral meniscus by drawing it posterolaterally during flexion of the knee and medial rotation of the tibia.

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Medial meniscus is less mobile. Option: C. Not thinner Option: D. Wrong statement.

The lateral collateral ligaments consist of the: Anterior taloﬁbular Posterior taloﬁbular Calcaneoﬁbular ligaments. In plantar flexion the ligament essentially changes its orientation from horizontal concerning the ﬂoor to almost vertical. questions.text: A 24-year-old male came with a history of twisting injury of the ankle after a road traffic accident. He complains of pain and swelling over the medial malleoli and an X-ray was taken. What is this injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Medial malleoli fracture with fibular head fracture

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Maisonneuve fracture Maisonneuve fracture is a spiral fracture of the proximal third of the fibula associated with a tear of distal tibiofibular syndesmosis and interosseous membrane . There is an associated fracture of the medial malleoli or rupture of the deltoid ligament of the ankle . It occurs due to pronation-external rotation type of injury. It is a counterpart of Essex Lopresti fracture.

Highyeild:

Maisonneuve fracture Consist of: Spiral fracture of the proximal fibula Unstable ankle injury, e.g. Widening of the ankle joint Distal tibiofibular syndesmosis disruption Deltoid ligament disruption Fracture of the medial or posterior malleolus Mechanism of injury. External rotation of ankle Management: Surgical fixation

X-Ray shows no bimalleolar fracture Option: C. Deltoid ligament injury is associated with high fibular fracture. Deltoid ligament injury is diagnosed with severe pain and swelling over the medial aspect of the ankle after a twisting injury.
